Award.AwardTitle: Improving Economic Resilience of the US Gulf Coast Communities to Coastal Hazards

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching goal of this research is to explore the relationship of economic vulnerability, resilience, and recovery in selected communities of the three coastal counties of Mississippi (Harrison, Hancock and Jackson). This project will compare vulnerability and resilience of these communities at finer scales of analysis (i.e. parcel and household level) than has been accomplished in past research. This project will: 1) identify factors contributing to spatial and temporal variations in vulnerability and resilience; 2) estimate errors in vulnerability and resilience assessments by comparing their results at different scales of analysis; and 3) identify variables that contribute to the recovery of these communities after disasters.

The results of this analysis will help answer why communities with similar socio-economic compositions and facing identical disasters have different vulnerabilities and recovery rates. The results of this research will directly benefit Gulf Coast communities in their efforts to increase their resilience towards tropical cyclones by providing insight into best and worst practices in mitigation policy. Other benefits of this project include: 1) increasing local participation in decision making regarding tropical cyclones; 2) aiding local policy makers in the design and deployment of effective mitigation and economic development policies; 3) complementing local efforts to increase community resilience; (4) developing game-based educational tools to increase student participation in research; (5) constructing a web-based Spatial Decision Support System that will provide a venue for local participation in decision-making; and (6) disseminating research outcomes through community outreach, conferences, and scientific publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Goals

The purpose of this research was to identify the factors that contribute to the resilience of coastal communities to coastal hazards and determine the effectiveness of public policy in enhancing recovery after disasters. This study was conducted in a sample of communities in the three coastal counties of Mississippi (Harrison, Hancock and Jackson). The following items represent the broader impacts and intellectual merits of this project:

Broader Impacts

  1. The findings of the project were used to create an educational manual about disaster preparedness, resilience, and vulnerability that was specifically suited to Gulf Coast communities. The manual was shared with the Gulf of Mexico Alliance and NAVASA-Boat People for public use. This document identifies all hazards the study site is susceptible to, the distribution of current physical risk and social vulnerability, and existing emergency preparedness and disaster mitigation practices and policies.
  2. A suite of analytical and visualization tools to assess risk, financial loss, and social vulnerability were created using Python. These tools can be used as stand-alone tools in ArcMap.
  3. A survey instrument was developed to collect data about risk perception, individual and community resilience, public participation in resilience building efforts, and psychological resilience of impacted populations. Although this instrument was used only on the Mississippi coast, it has broad applicability to other coastal areas in the northern Gulf of Mexico. 
  4. Geospatial data sets were generated for a variety of different variables: 1) Physical Factors (Coastlines, Digital Elevation Model, Areas of Storm Surge Impact and Floodplains, Rivers and Stream Networks); 2) Social Factors (Socio-economic and Demographic Characteristics); 3) Built Environment (Land Use/Land Cover, Building Footprints, Transportation Networks); and 4) Oil Spill Impact Area. Additionally, derived products pertaining to physical risk, social vulnerability and resilience were also generated.

 Intellectual Merits

  1. Communities of the Mississippi Gulf Coast are inherently at high risk to coastal hazards due to their physical proximity to the Gulf of Mexico. Although socio-economic factors contribute to individual resilience, community resilience is influenced by political factors and the availability of resources for community emergency services to respond in a timely manner after an extreme event. The social capital of specific communities (communities with low-income and low-education population) is a major inhibiting factor with regard to their resilience. Individuals within these communities rely as much or more on family and friend networks than community services in preparation and response to extreme events.
  2. The spatial scale of analysis influences overall vulnerability and resilience assessments; this fact is rarely considered in hazards research. Understanding the range of error associated with different spatial scales of analysis is critical for future research as well as for policy making and stakeholder preparedness.
  3. Existing techniques for vulnerability assessments tend to rank variables by comparing their values among the administrative boundaries within a single study site. This approach fails to assess the impact of individual variables on vulnerability. In this study, a different approach was used to rank variables such that the influence of each variable on overall vulnerability of an individual place was determined. Because some variables positively influence resilience at certain locations, comparing places based on their resilience requires identifying the variables that make a location resilient vs vulnerable. Place-based assessments are necessary to accurately measure community resilience.
  4. The risk perception of individuals in the study communities was found to be influenced by two main factors – age and past experience. Gender and other characteristics identified in the literature to influence risk perception were found to be non-significant. Residents of the study communities are aware of their risk to coastal hazards and are willing to take actions to increase their resilience. Community participation in policy preparation and resilience assessment was also found to be a major factor in increasing public awareness and willingness to take initiatives to improve resilience. Community organizations, such as NAVASA and Gulf of Mexico Alliance were found to be more effective in increasing public awareness, participation in resilience building efforts.
